natural problem: What is the largest three-digit integer $n$ that satisfies $$55n\equiv 165\pmod{260}~?$$
natural solution: First, we note that $55$, $165$, and $260$ all have a common factor of $5$: \begin{align} 55 &= 5\cdot 11\\ 165 &= 5\cdot 33\\ 260 &= 5\cdot 52 \end{align}An integer $n$ satisfies $55n\equiv 165\pmod{260}$ if and only if it satisfies $11n\equiv 33\pmod{52}$.

Now it is clear that $n=3$ is a solution. Moreover, since $11$ and $52$ are relatively prime, the solution is unique $\pmod{52}$. If you don't already know why this is the case, consider that we are looking for $n$ such that $11n-33=11(n-3)$ is divisible by $52$; this is true if and only if $n-3$ is divisible by $52$.

Hence all solutions are of the form $3+52k$, where $k$ is an integer. One such solution which is easy to compute is $3+52(20) = 1043$. The next-largest solution is $1043-52 = 991$, so the largest three-digit solution is $\boxed{991}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "55 * n mod 260 = 165"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 100"
and h2 : "n \<le> 999"
shows  "n = 991"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the largest three-digit integer $n$ that satisfies $$55n\equiv 165\pmod{260}~?$$ The final Answer is 991
 ### Proof
 First, we note that $55$, $165$, and $260$ all have a common factor of $5$: \begin{align} 55 &= 5\cdot 11\\ 165 &= 5\cdot 33\\ 260 &= 5\cdot 52 \end{align}An integer $n$ satisfies $55n\equiv 165\pmod{260}$ if and only if it satisfies $11n\equiv 33\pmod{52}$.
 (Make sure you see why!)
 Now it is clear that $n=3$ is a solution. Moreover, since $11$ and $52$ are relatively prime, the solution is unique $\pmod{52}$. If you don't already know why this is the case, consider that we are looking for $n$ such that $11n-33=11(n-3)$ is divisible by $52$; this is true if and only if $n-3$ is divisible by $52$.
 Hence all solutions are of the form $3+52k$, where $k$ is an integer. One such solution which is easy to compute is $3+52(20) = 1043$. The next-largest solution is $1043-52 = 991$, so the largest three-digit solution is $\boxed{991}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "55 * n mod 260 = 165"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 100"
and h2 : "n \<le> 999"
shows  "n = 991"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find an integer $n$ between 100 and 999 such that the remainder when $55n$ is divided by 260 equals 165. The final answer is 991.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "55 * n mod 260 = 165 mod 260"
and h1 : "100 \<le> n"
and h2 : "n \<le> 999"
shows  "n = 991"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the largest three-digit integer $n$ that satisfies $$55n\equiv 165\pmod{260}~?$$ The final Answer is 991
 ### Proof
 First, we note that $55$, $165$, and $260$ all have a common factor of $5$: \begin{align} 55 &= 5\cdot 11\\ 165 &= 5\cdot 33\\ 260 &= 5\cdot 52 \end{align}An integer $n$ satisfies $55n\equiv 165\pmod{260}$ if and only if it satisfies $11n\equiv 33\pmod{52}$.
 (Make sure you see why!)

If you don't already know why this is the case, consider that we are looking for $n$ such that $11n-33=11(n-3)$ is divisible by $52$; this is true if and only if $n-3$ is divisible by $52$.
 Hence all solutions are of the form $3+52k$, where $k$ is an integer. One such solution which is easy to compute is $3+52(20) = 1043$. The next-largest solution is $1043-52 = 991$, so the largest three-digit solution is $\boxed{991}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "55 * n mod 260 = 165 mod 260"
and h1 : "100 \<le> n"
and h2 : "n \<le> 999"
shows  "n = 991"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find an integer $n$ between 100 and 999 inclusive, such that when $55n$ is divided by 260, the remainder is the same as the remainder when 165 is divided by 260. The solution is $n = 991$.
